intro: Erioglossum alliaceum, commonly known as the garlic leek, is a flowering plant native to southern Africa. It belongs to the family Amaryllidaceae and is characterized by its basal rosette of narrow, garlic-scented leaves. The plant produces a tall, slender stem that bears clusters of white, bell-shaped flowers. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in rocky or gravelly habitats. Due to its ornamental value and unique fragrance, it is occasionally cultivated in gardens.
